t: Job 9
Job
Then*p Job replied:
“Indeed,*pn I know that this is true. But*ld how can mere mortals prove their innocence before God?
Though*ln they wished to dispute with him, they*ld could not answer him one time out of a thousand.
His*ln wisdom is profound, his power is vast. Who*ld has resisted him and come out unscathed?
He*ln moves mountains without their knowing it and*ld overturns them in his anger.
He*ln shakes the earth from its place and*ld makes its pillars tremble.
He*ln speaks to the sun and it does not shine; he*ld seals off the light of the stars.
He*ln alone stretches out the heavens and*ld treads on the waves of the sea.
He*ln is the Maker of the Bear and Orion, the*ld Pleiades and the constellations of the south.
He*ln performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles*ld that cannot be counted.
When*ln he passes me, I cannot see him; when*ld he goes by, I cannot perceive him.
If*ln he snatches away, who can stop him? Who*ld can say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
God*ln does not restrain his anger; even*ld the cohorts of Rahab cowered at his feet.
“How*pn then can I dispute with him? How*ld can I find words to argue with him?
Though*ln I were innocent, I could not answer him; I*ld could only plead with my Judge for mercy.
Even*ln if I summoned him and he responded, I*ld do not believe he would give me a hearing.
He*ln would crush me with a storm and*ld multiply my wounds for no reason.
He*ln would not let me catch my breath but*ld would overwhelm me with misery.
If*ln it is a matter of strength, he is mighty! And*ld if it is a matter of justice, who can challenge him?
Even*ln if I were innocent, my mouth would condemn me; if*ld I were blameless, it would pronounce me guilty.
“Although*pn I am blameless, I*ld have no concern for myself; I*ld despise my own life.
It*ln is all the same; that is why I say, ‘He*ld destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’
When*ln a scourge brings sudden death, he*ld mocks the despair of the innocent.
When*ln a land falls into the hands of the wicked, he*ld blindfolds its judges. If*ld it is not he, then who is it?
“My*pn days are swifter than a runner; they*ld fly away without a glimpse of joy.
They*ln skim past like boats of papyrus, like*ld eagles swooping down on their prey.
If*ln I say, ‘I will forget my complaint, I*ld will change my expression, and smile,’
I*ln still dread all my sufferings, for*ld I know you will not hold me innocent.
Since*ln I am already found guilty, why*ld should I struggle in vain?
Even*ln if I washed myself with soap and*ld my hands with cleansing powder,
you*ln would plunge me into a slime pit so*ld that even my clothes would detest me.
“He*pn is not a mere mortal like me that I might answer him, that*ld we might confront each other in court.
If*ln only there were someone to mediate between us, someone*ld to bring us together,
someone*ln to remove God’s rod from me, so*ld that his terror would frighten me no more.
Then*ln I would speak up without fear of him, but*ld as it now stands with me, I cannot.
